Introduction

The kidney contains millions of filtration units known as glomeruli, which are networks of capillaries supported by a structural matrix containing mesangial cells.  Glomerular capillaries are lined by endothelial cells and the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).  Together with specialized epithelial cells called podocytes, this network controls the passage of substances from the blood into the urinary (Bowman) space (ie, glomerular filtration (

figure 1
).  Damage to these glomerular structures can result in a variety of clinical manifestations ranging from subtle urinary changes to life-threatening kidney failure.

Pathophysiology



Mild forms of glomerular damage interfere with the normal filtration barrier and can cause isolated microscopic hematuria and/or proteinuria; this condition often presents without symptoms but warrants investigation to prevent progression.  More substantial glomerular injury can manifest as nephritic syndrome (inflammatory) or nephrotic syndrome (noninflammatory).

Nephritic syndrome



  • Widespread glomerular inflammation (ie, glomerulonephritis [GN]) affects all glomerular structures, significantly disrupting filtration and renal blood flow.
  • Red blood cells (RBCs) pass through damaged glomerular capillary walls, undergoing deformation (ie, dysmorphic RBCs) and precipitation within tubules (ie, RBC casts); this condition is known as glomerular hematuria.
  • Accumulation of inflammatory debris and RBCs within capillaries and tubules physically slows down glomerular filtration, leading to acute kidney injury and intravascular volume overload (eg, hypertension, mild edema).  This physical barrier also limits the amount of proteinuria that can occur (eg, 1-2 g/day).

Nephrotic syndrome



  • Isolated noninflammatory injury is largely limited to podocytes and the GBM without significant involvement of surrounding structures.
  • The glomerular filtration barrier becomes selectively permeable to small proteins (including albumin), resulting in massive urinary protein losses (>3.5 g/day) without significant glomerular hematuria (RBCs are too large to pass through the barrier).
  • Hypoalbuminemia reduces plasma oncotic pressure, promoting profound edema without intravascular volume overload.  Additional complications include hypercoagulability, hyperlipidemia (with lipiduria), bacterial infections, protein malnutrition, and intravascular volume depletion (

Mixed nephrotic-nephritic syndrome consists of features of both syndromes (

figure 2
).  It is less common and usually seen with membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN).

Etiologies and classification

Nephritic syndrome



Nephritic syndrome (diffuse inflammatory damage to the glomerulus) is often mediated by 2 mechanisms involving antibodies: either immune complex deposition or antibody-mediated cellular injury.  Examples and characteristics of diseases associated with each type are listed below.



  • Immune complex deposition:  Antigen-antibody complexes form in circulation or the glomerulus (as a result of an underlying disease process) and deposit in the GBM or mesangium, triggering complement activation and inflammation.

    • Lupus nephritis:  malar rash, synovitis
    • MPGN:  history of hepatitis C, cirrhosis
    • Infection-related GN
      • Poststreptococcal:  recent upper respiratory infection (URI) (postpharyngitic)
      • Staphylococcus-associated:  bacteremia, skin infection
      • Endocarditis-associated:  fever, murmur
    • IgA nephropathy:  concurrent URI (synpharyngitic)
  • Antibody-mediated cellular injury:  Antibodies target antigens, leading to direct cellular injury and activation of immune effector mechanisms.
    • Anti-GBM disease can cause hemoptysis if there is lung involvement (Goodpasture syndrome).
    • Pauci-immune GN (granulomatosis with polyangiitis [GPA], microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis [EGPA]):  systemic antineutrophil cytoplasmic autoantibody (ANCA)â€“associates vasculitides usually involving upper and lower respiratory tract

Nephrotic syndrome



Nephrotic syndrome (noninflammatory injury isolated to podocytes and the GBM) is due to either:



  • Systemic disease:  diabetes mellitus, amyloidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Renally limited conditions, which can be either primary (ie, initial insult in the kidney) or secondary:
    • Minimal change disease
      • Primary:  glomerular permeability factor (eg, IL-13)
      • Secondary:  nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), lymphoma, allergy (eg, pollen, insect stings)
    • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
      • Primary:  glomerular permeability factor (eg, suPAR)
      • Secondary:  hyperfiltration injury (eg, severe obesity, solitary kidney, reflux nephropathy), infections (eg, HIV, parvovirus B19), toxins (eg, heroin)
      • An advanced form of FSGS (usually seen in HIV-associated nephropathy) is known as collapsing glomerulopathy (associated with APOL1 polymorphisms).
    • Membranous nephropathy (MN)
      • Primary:  autoimmunity to normal podocyte antigens; most commonly positive for antiphospholipase A2 receptor (anti-PLA2R) antibodies
      • Secondary:  solid tumors, NSAIDs, SLE (class V nephropathy), hepatitis B and hepatitis C viruses

Evaluation

Nephritic syndrome



Nephritic syndrome evaluation should be performed in the setting of hematuria (especially with dysmorphic RBCs or RBC casts), AKI, and hypertension.  The first step is measurement of serum complement levels, which guides further diagnostic testing (

figure 3
).



  • Low complement (typically from immune-complex mediated conditions)

    • Antinuclear antibodies, antiâ€“double-stranded DNA:  lupus nephritis
    • Antiâ€“hepatitis C virus, cryoglobulins:  MPGN (often also has nephrotic features)
    • Antistreptolysin-O antibodies and/or anti-DNase antibodies:  poststreptococcal GN
    • Positive Staphylococcus cultures:  Staphylococcus-associated GN
    • Duke criteria:  infective endocarditis
  • Normal complement (typically from antibody-mediated conditions)
    • Anti-GBM antibodies:  anti-GBM/Goodpasture disease
    • ANCA:  pauci-immune GN (ANCA vasculitis)
    • Normal bloodwork:  IgA nephropathy (immune-complex mediated but with normal serum complement level likely due to IgA's limited ability to activate complement)


A presumptive diagnosis can often be made based on clinical history, physical examination, and complement levels, and treatment can be initiated while awaiting a confirmatory renal biopsy.

Nephrotic syndrome



Nephrotic syndrome evaluation should be performed in the setting of urinalysis findings of heavy proteinuria (3-4+) in addition to hypoalbuminemia and anasarca.  A spot urine-to-protein creatinine ratio is used to quantify the degree of proteinuria (results are roughly equivalent to 24-hour urine protein excretion).  A lipid panel typically shows hyperlipidemia.



Nephrotic syndrome in adults is often due to systemic disease (eg, diabetes mellitus, amyloidosis); if nephrotic syndrome can be attributed to these diseases (eg, advanced diabetes mellitus), then further diagnostic evaluation is typically not required.



Otherwise, a renal biopsy is required.  Serologic testing is not as helpful as in nephritic syndrome for narrowing the differential; an exception is positivity for anti-PLA2R antibodies, which can sometimes be diagnostic for primary MN without a biopsy.

Management



Management of both nephritic and nephrotic syndrome involves addressing the underlying cause, including systemic disease (eg, diabetes mellitus), underlying infections, autoimmune conditions, and immune system dysregulation.  ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers are commonly used to minimize proteinuria (nephrotic syndrome) and control blood pressure (nephritic syndrome).  Diuretics may be required in both.  In nephrotic syndrome, additional measures include statins for hyperlipidemia, prophylactic anticoagulation in high-risk patients, and pneumococcal vaccination.



Corticosteroids may be used in certain etiologies, particularly in nephrotic syndrome where many primary causes are driven by immune system dysregulation (eg, circulating factors targeting podocytes).  Somewhat paradoxically, glomerular inflammation in nephritic syndrome is often less responsive to corticosteroids and may respond to supportive treatment alone.  Some cases of either nephritic or nephrotic syndrome, particularly those with severe or refractory disease, may require other immunosuppressants (eg, cyclophosphamide, rituximab) or plasmapheresis.

Prognosis



Prognosis is highly variable and depends on etiology, age (eg, children more likely to have a benign course), extent of renal injury, and response to treatment.  Patient outcomes can range from complete recovery, development of stable chronic kidney disease, or fulminant renal failure (eg, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis) resulting in end-stage renal disease.  Dialysis (either short-term or long-term, depending on recovery) or renal transplantation for end-stage renal disease may be needed.  Early detection and appropriate interventions offer the best chance to preserve kidney function and prevent complications.

Summary



Nephritic and nephrotic syndromes represent spectrums of glomerular disease.  Nephritic syndrome, often antibody-mediated through immune complex deposition or direct antiâ€“glomerular basement membrane (GBM) activity, presents with glomerular inflammation leading to hematuria, hypertension, and acute kidney injury.  Nephrotic syndrome, typically resulting from noninflammatory damage to podocytes and the GBM, manifests with significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and significant edema.  Mixed forms can occur; evaluation is guided by the primary syndrome (nephritic vs nephrotic).
